_header: O worthy noble King Henry the fourth
Note:
Editions with unattrib. sources: Chalmers (1810)
XChalmers, Alexander. The Works of the English Poets from Chaucer to Cowper. London, 1810; repr. New York: Greenwood, 1969, 1. 548-51; Wright (1859)
XWright, Thomas. Political Poems and Songs relating to English History, composed during the period From the Accession of Edward III to that of Richard III. 2 vols. Rolls Series 14 (1859, 1861); repr. Kraus, 1965, 2.4-15; Skeat (1894)
XSkeat, Walter William. The Complete Works of Geoffrey Chaucer. 7 vols. Oxford: Clarendon, 1894-7, 7.205-16; Macaulay (1900)
XMacaulay, George Campbell. English Works of John Gower. 2 vols. EETS e.s. 81, 82 (1900, 1901); repr. 1978, 2.481-92.
_description: John Gower, In Praise of Peace — fifty-five stanzas rhyme royal with an introductory seven lines in Latin

BLAdd59495.First Lines:
O worþi noble Kyng Henry þe ferþeIn whom þe
                    glade fortune is befalle…
BLAdd59495.Last Lines:
…Kep charite and draugh pite to hondeMaintene lawe and so
                    þe pes schal stonde
BLAdd59495.Note: Eighteenth-century transcript is London,  British Library Addit. 59496.
BLAdd59495.Editions:
Forni,  Kathleen,
                        ed.  
             The Chaucerian
                    Apocrypha: A Selection.
